title: How to Remove Liquid Spills from Fabric Vehicle Upholstery

steps.title: Dab the spill with a dry washcloth or paper towel to absorb as much liquid as possible.
steps.content: Dab the spill with a dry washcloth or paper towel to absorb as much liquid as possible. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Spray vehicle upholstery cleaner onto the spill, or dab it on with the washcloth.
steps.content: Spray vehicle upholstery cleaner onto the spill, or dab it on with the washcloth. You can purchase upholstery cleaner formulated for car interiors, or use 1 part laundry detergent diluted in 2 parts warm water.

steps.title: Follow the instructions on the bottle of your upholstery cleaner.
steps.content: Follow the instructions on the bottle of your upholstery cleaner. Some may need to be vacuumed up after a certain amount of time setting into the spill. Others, including laundry soap and water, should be scrubbed into the spill. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub the spill using a dry terrycloth towel or a soft-bristle scrub brush.
steps.content: Scrub the spill using a dry terrycloth towel or a soft-bristle scrub brush.

steps.title: Blot excess cleaner or soap with a clean, dry paper towel or washcloth.
steps.content: Blot excess cleaner or soap with a clean, dry paper towel or washcloth.

steps.title: Soak a washcloth in lukewarm water, and dab it over the spill to wipe away any leftover soap residue.
steps.content: Soak a washcloth in lukewarm water, and dab it over the spill to wipe away any leftover soap residue.

steps.title: Park your car outside with the windows down to quickly dry the area of the spill.
steps.content: Park your car outside with the windows down to quickly dry the area of the spill. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Examine the spill once it has been cleaned and allowed to dry completely.
steps.content: Examine the spill once it has been cleaned and allowed to dry completely. If you can still see staining, repeat the process of scrubbing, rinsing and drying. [4] X Research source
